speech.line: Yes, one, and in this manner. He was to imagine me his love, his mistress; and I set him every day to woo me. At which time would I, being but a moonish youth, grieve, be effeminate, changeable, longing and liking, proud, fantastical, apish, shallow, inconstant, full of tears, full of smiles; for every passion something, and for no passion truly any thing, as boys and women are for the most part cattle of this color; would now like him, now loathe him; then entertain him, then forswear him; now weep for him, then spit at him; that I drave my suitor from his mad humor of love to a living humor of madness, which was, to forswear the full stream of the world, and to live in a nook merely monastic. And thus I cur’d him, and this way will I take upon me to wash your liver as clean as a sound sheep’s heart, that there shall not be one spot of love in’t.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: I would not be cur’d, youth.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I would cure you, if you would but call me Rosalind, and come every day to my cote and woo me.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Now, by the faith of my love, I will. Tell me where it is.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Go with me to it, and I’ll show it you; and by the way, you shall tell me where in the forest you live. Will you go?

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: With all my heart, good youth.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Nay, you must call me Rosalind. Come, sister, will you go?

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the Forest of Arden.

stagedir.dir: Enter Clown (Touchstone), Audrey; and Jaques behind.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Come apace, good Audrey; I will fetch up your goats, Audrey. And how, Audrey? Am I the man yet? Doth my simple feature content you?

speech.speaker: AUD.
speech.line: Your features, Lord warrant us! What features?

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: I am here with thee and thy goats as the most capricious poet, honest Ovid, was among the Goths.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: O knowledge ill-inhabited, worse than Jove in a thatch’d house!

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: When a man’s verses cannot be understood, nor a man’s good wit seconded with the forward child, understanding, it strikes a man more dead than a great reckoning in a little room. Truly, I would the gods had made thee poetical.

speech.speaker: AUD.
speech.line: I do not know what ‘poetical’ is. Is it honest in deed and word? Is it a true thing?

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: No, truly; for the truest poetry is the most feigning, and lovers are given to poetry; and what they swear in poetry may be said as lovers they do feign.

speech.speaker: AUD.
speech.line: Do you wish then that the gods had made me poetical?

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: I do, truly; for thou swear’st to me thou art honest. Now if thou wert a poet, I might have some hope thou didst feign.

speech.speaker: AUD.
speech.line: Would you not have me honest?

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: No, truly, unless thou wert hard-favor’d; for honesty coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: A material fool!

speech.speaker: AUD.
speech.line: Well, I am not fair, and therefore I pray the gods make me honest.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Truly, and to cast away honesty upon a foul slut were to put good meat into an unclean dish.

speech.speaker: AUD.
speech.line: I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Well, prais’d be the gods for thy foulness! Sluttishness may come hereafter. But be it as it may be, I will marry thee; and to that end I have been with Sir Oliver Martext, the vicar of the next village, who hath promis’d to meet me in this place of the forest and to couple us.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: I would fain see this meeting.

speech.speaker: AUD.
speech.line: Well, the gods give us joy!

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Amen. A man may, if he were of a fearful heart, stagger in this attempt; for here we have no temple but the wood, no assembly but horn-beasts. But what though? Courage! As horns are odious, they are necessary. It is said, “Many a man knows no end of his goods.” Right! Many a man has good horns, and knows no end of them. Well, that is the dowry of his wife, ’tis none of his own getting. Horns? Even so. Poor men alone? No, no, the noblest deer hath them as huge as the rascal. Is the single man therefore bless’d? No, as a wall’d town is more worthier than a village, so is the forehead of a married man more honorable than the bare brow of a bachelor; and by how much defense is better than no skill, by so much is a horn more precious than to want.
Here comes Sir Oliver. Sir Oliver Martext, you are well met. Will you dispatch us here under this tree, or shall we go with you to your chapel?

speech.speaker: SIR OLIV.
speech.line: Is there none here to give the woman?

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: I will not take her on gift of any man.

speech.speaker: SIR OLIV.
speech.line: Truly, she must be given, or the marriage is not lawful.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Proceed, proceed. I’ll give her.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Good even, good Master What-ye-call’t; how do you, sir? You are very well met. God ’ild you for your last company. I am very glad to see you. Even a toy in hand here, sir. Nay, pray be cover’d.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Will you be married, motley?

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: As the ox hath his bow, sir, the horse his curb, and the falcon her bells, so man hath his desires; and as pigeons bill, so wedlock would be nibbling.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: And will you (being a man of your breeding) be married under a bush like a beggar? Get you to church, and have a good priest that can tell you what marriage is. This fellow will but join you together as they join wainscot; then one of you will prove a shrunk panel, and like green timber warp, warp.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: I am not in the mind but I were better to be married of him than of another, for he is not like to marry me well; and not being well married, it will be a good excuse for me hereafter to leave my wife.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Go thou with me, and let me counsel thee.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Come, sweet Audrey,
We must be married, or we must live in bawdry.
Farewell, good Master Oliver: not
“O sweet Oliver,
O brave Oliver,
Leave me not behind thee;”
But
“Wind away,
Be gone, I say,
I will not to wedding with thee.”

speech.speaker: SIR OLIV.
speech.line: ’Tis no matter; ne’er a fantastical knave of them all shall flout me out of my calling.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the Forest of Arden.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Never talk to me, I will weep.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Do, I prithee, but yet have the grace to consider that tears do not become a man.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: But have I not cause to weep?

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: As good cause as one would desire, therefore weep.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: His very hair is of the dissembling color.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Something browner than Judas’s. Marry, his kisses are Judas’s own children.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I’ faith, his hair is of a good color.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: An excellent color. Your chestnut was ever the only color.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: And his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch of holy bread.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: He hath bought a pair of cast lips of Diana. A nun of winter’s sisterhood kisses not more religiously, the very ice of chastity is in them.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: But why did he swear he would come this morning, and comes not?

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Nay certainly there is no truth in him.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Do you think so?

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Yes, I think he is not a pick-purse nor a horse-stealer, but for his verity in love, I do think him as concave as a cover’d goblet or a worm-eaten nut.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Not true in love?

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Yes, when he is in—but I think he is not in.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: You have heard him swear downright he was.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: “Was” is not “is.” Besides, the oath of a lover is no stronger than the word of a tapster; they are both the confirmer of false reckonings. He attends here in the forest on the Duke your father.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I met the Duke yesterday, and had much question with him. He ask’d me of what parentage I was. I told him of as good as he, so he laugh’d and let me go. But what talk we of fathers, when there is such a man as Orlando?

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: O, that’s a brave man! He writes brave verses, speaks brave words, swears brave oaths, and breaks them bravely, quite traverse, athwart the heart of his lover, as a puisne tilter, that spurs his horse but on one side, breaks his staff like a noble goose. But all’s brave that youth mounts and folly guides. Who comes here?

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Mistress and master, you have oft inquired
After the shepherd that complain’d of love,
Who you saw sitting by me on the turf,
Praising the proud disdainful shepherdess
That was his mistress.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Well; and what of him?

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: If you will see a pageant truly play’d
Between the pale complexion of true love
And the red glow of scorn and proud disdain,
Go hence a little, and I shall conduct you,
If you will mark it.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: O, come, let us remove,
The sight of lovers feedeth those in love.
Bring us to this sight, and you shall say
I’ll prove a busy actor in their play.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the Forest of Arden.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Sweet Phebe, do not scorn me, do not, Phebe;
Say that you love me not, but say not so
In bitterness. The common executioner,
Whose heart th’ accustom’d sight of death makes hard,
Falls not the axe upon the humbled neck
But first begs pardon. Will you sterner be
Than he that dies and lives by bloody drops?

stagedir.dir: Enter, behind, Rosalind, Celia, and Corin.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: I would not be thy executioner;
I fly thee for I would not injure thee.
Thou tell’st me there is murder in mine eye:
’Tis pretty, sure, and very probable,
That eyes, that are the frail’st and softest things,
Who shut their coward gates on atomies,
Should be called tyrants, butchers, murderers!
Now I do frown on thee with all my heart,
And if mine eyes can wound, now let them kill thee.
Now counterfeit to swound; why, now fall down,
Or if thou canst not, O, for shame, for shame,
Lie not, to say mine eyes are murderers!
Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee;
Scratch thee but with a pin, and there remains
Some scar of it; lean upon a rush,
The cicatrice and capable impressure
Thy palm some moment keeps; but now mine eyes,
Which I have darted at thee, hurt thee not,
Nor I am sure there is no force in eyes
That can do hurt.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: O dear Phebe,
If ever (as that ever may be near)
You meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy,
Then shall you know the wounds invisible
That love’s keen arrows make.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: But till that time
Come not thou near me; and when that time comes,
Afflict me with thy mocks, pity me not,
As till that time I shall not pity thee.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: And why, I pray you? Who might be your mother,
That you insult, exult, and all at once,
Over the wretched? What though you have no beauty—
As, by my faith, I see no more in you
Than without candle may go dark to bed—
Must you be therefore proud and pitiless?
Why, what means this? Why do you look on me?
I see no more in you than in the ordinary
Of nature’s sale-work. ’Od’s my little life,
I think she means to tangle my eyes too!
No, faith, proud mistress, hope not after it.
’Tis not your inky brows, your black silk hair,
Your bugle eyeballs, nor your cheek of cream
That can entame my spirits to your worship.
You foolish shepherd, wherefore do you follow her,
Like foggy south, puffing with wind and rain?
You are a thousand times a properer man
Than she a woman. ’Tis such fools as you
That makes the world full of ill-favor’d children.
’Tis not her glass, but you that flatters her,
And out of you she sees herself more proper
Than any of her lineaments can show her.
But, mistress, know yourself, down on your knees,
And thank heaven, fasting, for a good man’s love;
For I must tell you friendly in your ear,
Sell when you can, you are not for all markets.
Cry the man mercy, love him, take his offer;
Foul is most foul, being foul to be a scoffer.
So take her to thee, shepherd. Fare you well.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: Sweet youth, I pray you chide a year together,
I had rather hear you chide than this man woo.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: He’s fall’n in love with your foulness— and she’ll fall in love with my anger. If it be so, as fast as she answers thee with frowning looks, I’ll sauce her with bitter words.—Why look you so upon me?

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: For no ill will I bear you.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I pray you do not fall in love with me,
For I am falser than vows made in wine.
Besides, I like you not. If you will know my house,
’Tis at the tuft of olives here hard by.
Will you go, sister? Shepherd, ply her hard.
Come, sister. Shepherdess, look on him better,
And be not proud; though all the world could see,
None could be so abus’d in sight as he.
Come, to our flock.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: Dead shepherd, now I find thy saw of might,
“Who ever lov’d that lov’d not at first sight?”

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Sweet Phebe—

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: Hah! What say’st thou, Silvius?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Sweet Phebe, pity me.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: Why, I am sorry for thee, gentle Silvius.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Where ever sorrow is, relief would be.
If you do sorrow at my grief in love,
By giving love, your sorrow and my grief
Were both extermin’d.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: Thou hast my love; is not that neighborly?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: I would have you.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: Why, that were covetousness.
Silvius, the time was that I hated thee;
And yet it is not that I bear thee love,
But since that thou canst talk of love so well,
Thy company, which erst was irksome to me,
I will endure; and I’ll employ thee too.
But do not look for further recompense
Than thine own gladness that thou art employ’d.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: So holy and so perfect is my love,
And I in such a poverty of grace,
That I shall think it a most plenteous crop
To glean the broken ears after the man
That the main harvest reaps. Loose now and then
A scatt’red smile, and that I’ll live upon.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: Know’st thou the youth that spoke to me yerwhile?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Not very well, but I have met him oft,
And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds
That the old carlot once was master of.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: Think not I love him, though I ask for him;
’Tis but a peevish boy—yet he talks well—
But what care I for words? Yet words do well
When he that speaks them pleases those that hear.
It is a pretty youth—not very pretty—
But sure he’s proud—and yet his pride becomes him.
He’ll make a proper man. The best thing in him
Is his complexion; and faster than his tongue
Did make offense, his eye did heal it up.
He is not very tall—yet for his years he’s tall;
His leg is but so so—and yet ’tis well;
There was a pretty redness in his lip,
A little riper and more lusty red
Than that mix’d in his cheek; ’twas just the difference
Betwixt the constant red and mingled damask.
There be some women, Silvius, had they mark’d him
In parcels as I did, would have gone near
To fall in love with him; but for my part
I love him not, nor hate him not; and yet
Have more cause to hate him than to love him,
For what had he to do to chide at me?
He said mine eyes were black and my hair black,
And, now I am rememb’red, scorn’d at me.
I marvel why I answer’d not again.
But that’s all one; omittance is no quittance.
I’ll write to him a very taunting letter,
And thou shalt bear it; wilt thou, Silvius?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Phebe, with all my heart.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: I’ll write it straight;
The matter’s in my head and in my heart.
I will be bitter with him and passing short.
Go with me, Silvius.

scene.scenelocation: The Forest of Arden.

stagedir.dir: Enter Rosalind and Celia and Jaques.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: I prithee, pretty youth, let me be better acquainted with thee.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: They say you are a melancholy fellow.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: I am so; I do love it better than laughing.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Those that are in extremity of either are abominable fellows, and betray themselves to every modern censure worse than drunkards.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Why, ’tis good to be sad and say nothing.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Why then ’tis good to be a post.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: I have neither the scholar’s melancholy, which is emulation; nor the musician’s, which is fantastical; nor the courtier’s, which is proud; nor the soldier’s, which is ambitious; nor the lawyer’s, which is politic; nor the lady’s, which is nice; nor the lover’s, which is all these: but it is a melancholy of mine own, compounded of many simples, extracted from many objects, and indeed the sundry contemplation of my travels, in which my often rumination wraps me in a most humorous sadness.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: A traveler! By my faith, you have great reason to be sad. I fear you have sold your own lands to see other men’s; then to have seen much, and to have nothing, is to have rich eyes and poor hands.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Yes, I have gain’d my experience.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: And your experience makes you sad. I had rather have a fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad—and to travel for it too!

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Good day and happiness, dear Rosalind!

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Nay then God buy you, and you talk in blank verse.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Farewell, Monsieur Traveler: look you lisp and wear strange suits; disable all the benefits of your own country; be out of love with your nativity, and almost chide God for making you that countenance you are; or I will scarce think you have swam in a gundello.
Why, how now, Orlando, where have you been all this while? You a lover! And you serve me such another trick, never come in my sight more.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my promise.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Break an hour’s promise in love! He that will divide a minute into a thousand parts, and break but a part of the thousand part of a minute in the affairs of love, it may be said of him that Cupid hath clapp’d him o’ th’ shoulder, but I’ll warrant him heart-whole.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Pardon me, dear Rosalind.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Nay, and you be so tardy, come no more in my sight. I had as lief be woo’d of a snail.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Of a snail?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Ay, of a snail; for though he comes slowly, he carries his house on his head; a better jointure I think than you make a woman. Besides, he brings his destiny with him.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: What’s that?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Why, horns! Which such as you are fain to be beholding to your wives for. But he comes arm’d in his fortune, and prevents the slander of his wife.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Virtue is no horn-maker; and my Rosalind is virtuous.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: And I am your Rosalind.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: It pleases him to call you so; but he hath a Rosalind of a better leer than you.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Come, woo me, woo me; for now I am in a holiday humor, and like enough to consent. What would you say to me now, and I were your very very Rosalind?

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: I would kiss before I spoke.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Nay, you were better speak first, and when you were gravell’d for lack of matter, you might take occasion to kiss. Very good orators when they are out, they will spit, and for lovers lacking (God warn us!) matter, the cleanliest shift is to kiss.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: How if the kiss be denied?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Then she puts you to entreaty, and there begins new matter.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Who could be out, being before his belov’d mistress?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Marry, that should you if I were your mistress, or I should think my honesty ranker than my wit.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: What, of my suit?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Not out of your apparel, and yet out of your suit. Am not I your Rosalind?

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: I take some joy to say you are, because I would be talking of her.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Well, in her person, I say I will not have you.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Then in mine own person, I die.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: No, faith, die by attorney. The poor world is almost six thousand years old, and in all this time there was not any man died in his own person, videlicet, in a love-cause. Troilus had his brains dash’d out with a Grecian club, yet he did what he could to die before, and he is one of the patterns of love. Leander, he would have liv’d many a fair year though Hero had turn’d nun, if it had not been for a hot midsummer night; for, good youth, he went but forth to wash him in the Hellespont, and being taken with the cramp was drown’d; and the foolish chroniclers of that age found it was—Hero of Sestos. But these are all lies: men have died from time to time, and worms have eaten them, but not for love.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: I would not have my right Rosalind of this mind, for I protest her frown might kill me.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: By this hand, it will not kill a fly. But come, now I will be your Rosalind in a more coming-on disposition; and ask me what you will, I will grant it.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Then love me, Rosalind.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Yes, faith, will I, Fridays and Saturdays and all.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: And wilt thou have me?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Ay, and twenty such.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: What sayest thou?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Are you not good?

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: I hope so.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Why then, can one desire too much of a good thing? Come, sister, you shall be the priest, and marry us. Give me your hand, Orlando. What do you say, sister?

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Pray thee marry us.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: I cannot say the words.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: You must begin, “Will you, Orlando”—

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Go to! Will you, Orlando, have to wife this Rosalind?

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: I will.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Ay, but when?

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Why, now, as fast as she can marry us.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Then you must say, “I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.”

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I might ask you for your commission, but I do take thee, Orlando, for my husband. There’s a girl goes before the priest, and certainly a woman’s thought runs before her actions.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: So do all thoughts, they are wing’d.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Now tell me how long you would have her after you have possess’d her.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Forever and a day.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Say “a day,” without the “ever.” No, no, Orlando, men are April when they woo, December when they wed; maids are May when they are maids, but the sky changes when they are wives. I will be more jealous of thee than a Barbary cock-pigeon over his hen, more clamorous than a parrot against rain, more new-fangled than an ape, more giddy in my desires than a monkey. I will weep for nothing, like Diana in the fountain, and I will do that when you are dispos’d to be merry. I will laugh like a hyen, and that when thou art inclin’d to sleep.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: But will my Rosalind do so?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: By my life, she will do as I do.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: O, but she is wise.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Or else she could not have the wit to do this; the wiser, the waywarder. Make the doors upon a woman’s wit, and it will out at the casement; shut that, and ’twill out at the key-hole; stop that, ’twill fly with the smoke out at the chimney.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say, “Wit, whither wilt?”

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Nay, you might keep that check for it, till you met your wive’s wit going to your neighbor’s bed.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: And what wit could wit have to excuse that?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Marry, to say she came to seek you there. You shall never take her without her answer, unless you take her without her tongue. O, that woman that cannot make her fault her husband’s occasion, let her never nurse her child herself, for she will breed it like a fool!

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: For these two hours, Rosalind, I will leave thee.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Alas, dear love, I cannot lack thee two hours!

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: I must attend the Duke at dinner. By two a’ clock I will be with thee again.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Ay, go your ways, go your ways; I knew what you would prove; my friends told me as much, and I thought no less. That flattering tongue of yours won me. ’Tis but one cast away, and so come death! Two a’ clock is your hour?

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Ay, sweet Rosalind.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: By my troth, and in good earnest, and so God mend me, and by all pretty oaths that are not dangerous, if you break one jot of your promise, or come one minute behind your hour, I will think you the most pathetical break-promise, and the most hollow lover, and the most unworthy of her you call Rosalind, that may be chosen out of the gross band of the unfaithful; therefore beware my censure, and keep your promise.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my Rosalind; so adieu.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Well, Time is the old justice that examines all such offenders, and let Time try. Adieu.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: You have simply misus’d our sex in your love-prate. We must have your doublet and hose pluck’d over your head, and show the world what the bird hath done to her own nest.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thou didst know how many fathom deep I am in love! But it cannot be sounded; my affection hath an unknown bottom, like the bay of Portugal.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Or rather, bottomless—that as fast as you pour affection in, it runs out.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: No, that same wicked bastard of Venus that was begot of thought, conceiv’d of spleen, and born of madness, that blind rascally boy that abuses every one’s eyes because his own are out, let him be judge how deep I am in love. I’ll tell thee, Aliena, I cannot be out of the sight of Orlando. I’ll go find a shadow, and sigh till he come.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: And I’ll sleep.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the Forest of Arden.

stagedir.dir: Enter Jaques and Lords as foresters.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Which is he that kill’d the deer?

speech.speaker: 1. LORD. ARD.
speech.line: Sir, it was I.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Let’s present him to the Duke like a Roman conqueror, and it would do well to set the deer’s horns upon his head, for a branch of victory. Have you no song, forester, for this purpose?

speech.speaker: 2. LORD. ARD.
speech.line: Yes, sir.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Sing it. ’Tis no matter how it be in tune, so it make noise enough.

speech.speaker: 2. LORD. ARD.
speech.line: What shall he have that kill’d the deer?
His leather skin and horns to wear.
Then sing him home.
The rest shall bear this burden.
Take thou no scorn to wear the horn,
It was a crest ere thou wast born;
Thy father’s father wore it,
And thy father bore it.
The horn, the horn, the lusty horn
Is not a thing to laugh to scorn.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the Forest of Arden.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: How say you now? Is it not past two a’ clock? And here much Orlando!

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: I warrant you, with pure love and troubled brain, he hath ta’en his bow and arrows and is gone forth—to sleep. Look who comes here.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: My errand is to you, fair youth,
My gentle Phebe did bid me give you this.
I know not the contents, but as I guess
By the stern brow and waspish action
Which she did use as she was writing of it,
It bears an angry tenure. Pardon me,
I am but as a guiltless messenger.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Patience herself would startle at this letter,
And play the swaggerer: bear this, bear all!
She says I am not fair, that I lack manners;
She calls me proud, and that she could not love me
Were man as rare as phoenix. ’Od’s my will,
Her love is not the hare that I do hunt;
Why writes she so to me? Well, shepherd, well,
This is a letter of your own device.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: No, I protest, I know not the contents,
Phebe did write it.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Come, come, you are a fool,
And turn’d into the extremity of love.
I saw her hand, she has a leathern hand,
A freestone-colored hand. I verily did think
That her old gloves were on, but ’twas her hands;
She has a huswive’s hand—but that’s no matter.
I say she never did invent this letter,
This is a man’s invention and his hand.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Sure it is hers.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Why, ’tis a boisterous and a cruel style,
A style for challengers. Why, she defies me,
Like Turk to Christian. Women’s gentle brain
Could not drop forth such giant-rude invention,
Such Ethiop words, blacker in their effect
Than in their countenance. Will you hear the letter?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: So please you, for I never heard it yet;
Yet heard too much of Phebe’s cruelty.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: She Phebes me. Mark how the tyrant writes.

line.recite: “Art thou god to shepherd turn’d,
That a maiden’s heart hath burn’d?”

speech.line: Can a woman rail thus?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Call you this railing?

line.recite: “Why, thy godhead laid apart,
Warr’st thou with a woman’s heart?”
Did you ever hear such railing?
“Whiles the eye of man did woo me,
That could do no vengeance to me.”
Meaning me a beast.
“If the scorn of your bright eyne
Have power to raise such love in mine,
Alack, in me what strange effect
Would they work in mild aspect?
Whiles you chid me, I did love;
How then might your prayers move?
He that brings this love to thee
Little knows this love in me;
And by him seal up thy mind,
Whether that thy youth and kind
Will the faithful offer take
Of me, and all that I can make,
Or else by him my love deny,
And then I’ll study how to die.”

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Call you this chiding?

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Alas, poor shepherd!

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Do you pity him? No, he deserves no pity. Wilt thou love such a woman? What, to make thee an instrument, and play false strains upon thee? Not to be endur’d! Well, go your way to her (for I see love hath made thee a tame snake) and say this to her: that if she love me, I charge her to love thee; if she will not, I will never have her unless thou entreat for her. If you be a true lover, hence, and not a word; for here comes more company.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Good morrow, fair ones. Pray you (if you know)
Where in the purlieus of this forest stands
A sheep-cote fenc’d about with olive-trees?

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: West of this place, down in the neighbor bottom,
The rank of osiers by the murmuring stream
Left on your right hand brings you to the place.
But at this hour the house doth keep itself,
There’s none within.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: If that an eye may profit by a tongue,
Then should I know you by description—
Such garments and such years. “The boy is fair,
Of female favor, and bestows himself
Like a ripe sister; the woman low,
And browner than her brother.” Are not you
The owner of the house I did inquire for?

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: It is no boast, being ask’d, to say we are.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Orlando doth commend him to you both,
And to that youth he calls his Rosalind
He sends this bloody napkin. Are you he?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I am. What must we understand by this?

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Some of my shame, if you will know of me
What man I am, and how, and why, and where
This handkercher was stain’d.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: I pray you tell it.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: When last the young Orlando parted from you
He left a promise to return again
Within an hour, and pacing through the forest,
Chewing the food of sweet and bitter fancy,
Lo what befell! He threw his eye aside,
And mark what object did present itself
Under an old oak, whose boughs were moss’d with age
And high top bald with dry antiquity:
A wretched ragged man, o’ergrown with hair,
Lay sleeping on his back; about his neck
A green and gilded snake had wreath’d itself,
Who with her head nimble in threats approach’d
The opening of his mouth; but suddenly
Seeing Orlando, it unlink’d itself,
And with indented glides did slip away
Into a bush, under which bush’s shade
A lioness, with udders all drawn dry,
Lay couching, head on ground, with cat-like watch
When that the sleeping man should stir; for ’tis
The royal disposition of that beast
To prey on nothing that doth seem as dead.
This seen, Orlando did approach the man,
And found it was his brother, his elder brother.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: O, I have heard him speak of that same brother,
And he did render him the most unnatural
That liv’d amongst men.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: And well he might so do,
For well I know he was unnatural.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: But to Orlando: did he leave him there,
Food to the suck’d and hungry lioness?

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Twice did he turn his back, and purpos’d so;
But kindness, nobler ever than revenge,
And nature, stronger than his just occasion,
Made him give battle to the lioness,
Who quickly fell before him, in which hurtling
From miserable slumber I awaked.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Are you his brother?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Was’t you he rescu’d?

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Was’t you that did so oft contrive to kill him?

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: ’Twas I; but ’tis not I. I do not shame
To tell you what I was, since my conversion
So sweetly tastes, being the thing I am.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: But for the bloody napkin?

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: By and by.
When from the first to last betwixt us two
Tears our recountments had most kindly bath’d,
As how I came into that desert place—
In brief, he led me to the gentle Duke,
Who gave me fresh array and entertainment,
Committing me unto my brother’s love,
Who led me instantly unto his cave,
There stripp’d himself, and here upon his arm
The lioness had torn some flesh away,
Which all this while had bled; and now he fainted,
And cried in fainting upon Rosalind.
Brief, I recover’d him, bound up his wound,
And after some small space, being strong at heart,
He sent me hither, stranger as I am,
To tell this story, that you might excuse
His broken promise, and to give this napkin,
Dy’d in his blood, unto the shepherd youth
That he in sport doth call his Rosalind.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Why, how now, Ganymede, sweet Ganymede?

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Many will swoon when they do look on blood.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: There is more in it. Cousin Ganymede!

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Look, he recovers.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I would I were at home.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: We’ll lead you thither.
I pray you, will you take him by the arm?

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Be of good cheer, youth. You a man?
You lack a man’s heart.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I do so, I confess it. Ah, sirrah, a body would think this was well counterfeited! I pray you tell your brother how well I counterfeited. Heigh-ho!

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: This was not counterfeit, there is too great testimony in your complexion that it was a passion of earnest.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Counterfeit, I assure you.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Well then, take a good heart and counterfeit to be a man.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: So I do; but i’ faith, I should have been a woman by right.

speech.speaker: CEL.
speech.line: Come, you look paler and paler. Pray you draw homewards. Good sir, go with us.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: That will I, for I must bear answer back
How you excuse my brother, Rosalind.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I shall devise something; but I pray you commend my counterfeiting to him. Will you go?

scene.scenelocation: The Forest of Arden.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: We shall find a time, Audrey, patience, gentle Audrey.

speech.speaker: AUD.
speech.line: Faith, the priest was good enough, for all the old gentleman’s saying.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: A most wicked Sir Oliver, Audrey, a most vile Martext. But, Audrey, there is a youth here in the forest lays claim to you.

speech.speaker: AUD.
speech.line: Ay, I know who ’tis; he hath no interest in me in the world. Here comes the man you mean.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: It is meat and drink to me to see a clown. By my troth, we that have good wits have much to answer for; we shall be flouting; we cannot hold.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Good ev’n, Audrey.

speech.speaker: AUD.
speech.line: God ye good ev’n, William.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: And good ev’n to you, sir.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Good ev’n, gentle friend. Cover thy head, cover thy head; nay, prithee be cover’d. How old are you, friend?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Five and twenty, sir.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: A ripe age. Is thy name William?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: William, sir.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: A fair name. Wast born i’ the forest here?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Ay, sir, I thank God.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: “Thank God”—a good answer. Art rich?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Faith, sir, so, so.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: “So, so” is good, very good, very excellent good; and yet it is not, it is but so, so. Art thou wise?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Ay, sir, I have a pretty wit.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Why, thou say’st well. I do now remember a saying, “The fool doth think he is wise, but the wise man knows himself to be a fool.” The heathen philosopher, when he had a desire to eat a grape, would open his lips when he put it into his mouth, meaning thereby that grapes were made to eat and lips to open. You do love this maid?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: I do, sir.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Give me your hand. Art thou learned?

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: No, sir.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Then learn this of me: to have, is to have. For it is a figure in rhetoric that drink, being pour’d out of a cup into a glass, by filling the one doth empty the other. For all your writers do consent that ipse is he: now, you are not ipse, for I am he.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: Which he, sir?

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: He, sir, that must marry this woman. Therefore, you clown, abandon—which is in the vulgar leave—the society—which in the boorish is company—of this female—which in the common is woman; which together is, abandon the society of this female, or, clown, thou perishest; or to thy better understanding, diest; or (to wit) I kill thee, make thee away, translate thy life into death, thy liberty into bondage. I will deal in poison with thee, or in bastinado, or in steel; I will bandy with thee in faction; I will o’errun thee with policy; I will kill thee a hundred and fifty ways: therefore tremble and depart.

speech.speaker: AUD.
speech.line: Do, good William.

speech.speaker: WILL.
speech.line: God rest you merry, sir.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Our master and mistress seeks you. Come away, away!

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Trip, Audrey, trip, Audrey! I attend, I attend.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the Forest of Arden.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Is’t possible that on so little acquaintance you should like her? That but seeing, you should love her? And loving, woo? And wooing, she should grant? And will you persever to enjoy her?

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: Neither call the giddiness of it in question, the poverty of her, the small acquaintance, my sudden wooing, nor her sudden consenting; but say with me, I love Aliena; say with her that she loves me; consent with both that we may enjoy each other. It shall be to your good; for my father’s house and all the revenue that was old Sir Rowland’s will I estate upon you, and here live and die a shepherd.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: You have my consent. Let your wedding be tomorrow; thither will I invite the Duke and all ’s contented followers. Go you and prepare Aliena; for look you, here comes my Rosalind.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: God save you, brother.

speech.speaker: OLIV.
speech.line: And you, fair sister.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: O my dear Orlando, how it grieves me to see thee wear thy heart in a scarf!

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: It is my arm.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws of a lion.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Wounded it is, but with the eyes of a lady.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Did your brother tell you how I counterfeited to sound when he show’d me your handkercher?

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Ay, and greater wonders than that.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: O, I know where you are. Nay, ’tis true. There was never any thing so sudden but the fight of two rams, and Caesar’s thrasonical brag of “I came, saw, and overcame.” For your brother and my sister no sooner met but they look’d; no sooner look’d but they lov’d; no sooner lov’d but they sigh’d; no sooner sigh’d but they ask’d one another the reason; no sooner knew the reason but they sought the remedy: and in these degrees have they made a pair of stairs to marriage, which they will climb incontinent, or else be incontinent before marriage. They are in the very wrath of love, and they will together. Clubs cannot part them.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: They shall be married tomorrow; and I will bid the Duke to the nuptial. But O, how bitter a thing it is to look into happiness through another man’s eyes! By so much the more shall I tomorrow be at the height of heart-heaviness, by how much I shall think my brother happy in having what he wishes for.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Why then tomorrow I cannot serve your turn for Rosalind?

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: I can live no longer by thinking.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I will weary you then no longer with idle talking. Know of me then (for now I speak to some purpose) that I know you are a gentleman of good conceit. I speak not this that you should bear a good opinion of my knowledge, insomuch I say I know you are; neither do I labor for a greater esteem than may in some little measure draw a belief from you, to do yourself good, and not to grace me. Believe then, if you please, that I can do strange things. I have, since I was three year old, convers’d with a magician, most profound in his art, and yet not damnable. If you do love Rosalind so near the heart as your gesture cries it out, when your brother marries Aliena, shall you marry her. I know into what straits of fortune she is driven, and it is not impossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient to you, to set her before your eyes tomorrow, human as she is, and without any danger.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Speak’st thou in sober meanings?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: By my life I do, which I tender dearly, though I say I am a magician. Therefore put you in your best array, bid your friends; for if you will be married tomorrow, you shall; and to Rosalind, if you will.
Look, here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: Youth, you have done me much ungentleness,
To show the letter that I writ to you.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I care not if I have. It is my study
To seem despiteful and ungentle to you.
You are there followed by a faithful shepherd—
Look upon him, love him; he worships you.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: Good shepherd, tell this youth what ’tis to love.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: It is to be all made of sighs and tears,
And so am I for Phebe.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: And I for Ganymede.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: And I for Rosalind.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: And I for no woman.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: It is to be all made of faith and service,
And so am I for Phebe.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: And I for Ganymede.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: And I for Rosalind.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: And I for no woman.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: It is to be all made of fantasy,
All made of passion, and all made of wishes,
All adoration, duty, and observance,
All humbleness, all patience, and impatience,
All purity, all trial, all observance;
And so am I for Phebe.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: And so am I for Ganymede.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: And so am I for Rosalind.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: And so am I for no woman.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Why do you speak too, “Why blame you me to love you?”

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: To her that is not here, nor doth not hear.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Pray you no more of this, ’tis like the howling of Irish wolves against the moon.
I will help you if I can.
I would love you if I could.—Tomorrow meet me all together.
I will marry you, if ever I marry woman, and I’ll be married tomorrow.
I will satisfy you, if ever I satisfied man, and you shall be married tomorrow.
I will content you, if what pleases you contents you, and you shall be married tomorrow.
As you love Rosalind, meet.
As you love Phebe, meet. And as I love no woman, I’ll meet. So fare you well; I have left you commands.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: I’ll not fail, if I live.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: Nor I.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: Nor I.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the Forest of Arden.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Tomorrow is the joyful day, Audrey, tomorrow will we be married.

speech.speaker: AUD.
speech.line: I do desire it with all my heart; and I hope it is no dishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the world. Here come two of the banish’d Duke’s pages.

speech.speaker: 1. PAGE.
speech.line: Well met, honest gentleman.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: By my troth, well met. Come, sit, sit, and a song.

speech.speaker: 2. PAGE.
speech.line: We are for you, sit i’ th’ middle.

speech.speaker: 1. PAGE.
speech.line: Shall we clap into’t roundly, without hawking or spitting or saying we are hoarse, which are the only prologues to a bad voice?

speech.speaker: 2. PAGE.
speech.line: I’ faith, i’ faith, and both in a tune, like two gypsies on a horse.
It was a lover and his lass,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
That o’er the green corn-field did pass,
In spring time, the only pretty ring time,
When birds do sing, hey ding a ding, ding,
Sweet lovers love the spring.
Between the acres of the rye,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
These pretty country folks would lie,
In spring time, etc.
This carol they began that hour,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
How that a life was but a flower,
In spring time, etc.
And therefore take the present time,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
For love is crowned with the prime,
In spring time, etc.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Truly, young gentlemen, though there was no great matter in the ditty, yet the note was very untuneable.

speech.speaker: 1. PAGE.
speech.line: You are deceiv’d, sir, we kept time, we lost not our time.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: By my troth, yes; I count it but time lost to hear such a foolish song. God buy you, and God mend your voices! Come, Audrey.

scene.scenelocation: Another part of the Forest of Arden.

stagedir.dir: Enter Duke Senior, Amiens, Jaques, Orlando, Oliver, Celia.

speech.speaker: DUKE S.
speech.line: Dost thou believe, Orlando, that the boy
Can do all this that he hath promised?

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: I sometimes do believe, and sometimes do not,
As those that fear they hope, and know they fear.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: Patience once more, whiles our compact is urg’d:
You say, if I bring in your Rosalind,
You will bestow her on Orlando here?

speech.speaker: DUKE S.
speech.line: That would I, had I kingdoms to give with her.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: And you say you will have her, when I bring her.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: That would I, were I of all kingdoms king.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: You say you’ll marry me, if I be willing?

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: That will I, should I die the hour after.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: But if you do refuse to marry me,
You’ll give yourself to this most faithful shepherd?

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: So is the bargain.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: You say that you’ll have Phebe, if she will?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Though to have her and death were both one thing.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I have promis’d to make all this matter even:
Keep you your word, O Duke, to give your daughter;
You, yours, Orlando, to receive his daughter;
Keep you your word, Phebe, that you’ll marry me,
Or else, refusing me, to wed this shepherd;
Keep your word, Silvius, that you’ll marry her
If she refuse me; and from hence I go
To make these doubts all even.

speech.speaker: DUKE S.
speech.line: I do remember in this shepherd boy
Some lively touches of my daughter’s favor.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: My lord, the first time that I ever saw him
Methought he was a brother to your daughter.
But, my good lord, this boy is forest-born,
And hath been tutor’d in the rudiments
Of many desperate studies by his uncle,
Whom he reports to be a great magician,
Obscured in the circle of this forest.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: There is sure another flood toward, and these couples are coming to the ark. Here comes a pair of very strange beasts, which in all tongues are call’d fools.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Salutation and greeting to you all!

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Good my lord, bid him welcome. This is the motley-minded gentleman that I have so often met in the forest. He hath been a courtier, he swears.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: If any man doubt that, let him put me to my purgation. I have trod a measure, I have flatt’red a lady, I have been politic with my friend, smooth with mine enemy, I have undone three tailors, I have had four quarrels, and like to have fought one.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: And how was that ta’en up?

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Faith, we met, and found the quarrel was upon the seventh cause.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: How seventh cause? Good my lord, like this fellow.

speech.speaker: DUKE S.
speech.line: I like him very well.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: God ’ild you, sir, I desire you of the like. I press in here, sir, amongst the rest of the country copulatives, to swear and to forswear, according as marriage binds and blood breaks. A poor virgin, sir, an ill-favor’d thing, sir, but mine own; a poor humor of mine, sir, to take that that no man else will. Rich honesty dwells like a miser, sir, in a poor house, as your pearl in your foul oyster.

speech.speaker: DUKE S.
speech.line: By my faith, he is very swift and sententious.

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: According to the fool’s bolt, sir, and such dulcet diseases.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: But for the seventh cause—how did you find the quarrel on the seventh cause?

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: Upon a lie seven times remov’d (bear your body more seeming, Audrey), as thus, sir. I did dislike the cut of a certain courtier’s beard. He sent me word, if I said his beard was not cut well, he was in the mind it was: this is call’d the Retort Courteous. If I sent him word again, it was not well cut, he would send me word he cut it to please himself: this is call’d the Quip Modest. If again, it was not well cut, he disabled my judgment: this is call’d the Reply Churlish. If again, it was not well cut, he would answer I spake not true: this is call’d the Reproof Valiant. If again, it was not well cut, he would say I lie: this is call’d the Countercheck Quarrelsome; and so to Lie Circumstantial and the Lie Direct.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: And how oft did you say his beard was not well cut?

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: I durst go no further than the Lie Circumstantial, nor he durst not give me the Lie Direct; and so we measur’d swords and parted.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Can you nominate in order now the degrees of the lie?

speech.speaker: TOUCH.
speech.line: O sir, we quarrel in print, by the book—as you have books for good manners. I will name you the degrees. The first, the Retort Courteous; the second, the Quip Modest; the third, the Reply Churlish; the fourth, the Reproof Valiant; the fift, the Countercheck Quarrelsome; the sixt, the Lie with Circumstance; the seventh, the Lie Direct. All these you may avoid but the Lie Direct; and you may avoid that too, with an If. I knew when seven justices could not take up a quarrel, but when the parties were met themselves, one of them thought but of an If, as, “If you said so, then I said so”; and they shook hands and swore brothers. Your If is the only peacemaker; much virtue in If.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Is not this a rare fellow, my lord? He’s as good at any thing, and yet a fool.

speech.speaker: DUKE S.
speech.line: He uses his folly like a stalking-horse, and under the presentation of that he shoots his wit.

stagedir.dir: Enter Hymen, Rosalind, and Celia. Still music.

speech.speaker: HYM.
speech.line: Then is there mirth in heaven,
When earthly things made even
Atone together.
Good Duke, receive thy daughter,
Hymen from heaven brought her,
Yea, brought her hither,
That thou mightst join her hand with his
Whose heart within his bosom is.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: To you I give myself, for I am yours.
To you I give myself, for I am yours.

speech.speaker: DUKE S.
speech.line: If there be truth in sight, you are my daughter.

speech.speaker: ORL.
speech.line: If there be truth in sight, you are my Rosalind.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: If sight and shape be true,
Why then my love adieu!

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: I’ll have no father, if you be not he;
I’ll have no husband, if you be not he;
Nor ne’er wed woman, if you be not she.

speech.speaker: HYM.
speech.line: Peace ho! I bar confusion,
’Tis I must make conclusion
Of these most strange events.
Here’s eight that must take hands
To join in Hymen’s bands,
If truth holds true contents.
You and you no cross shall part;
You and you are heart in heart;
You to his love must accord,
Or have a woman to your lord;
You and you are sure together,
As the winter to foul weather.—
Whiles a wedlock-hymn we sing,
Feed yourselves with questioning;
That reason wonder may diminish
How thus we met, and these things finish.
Wedding is great Juno’s crown,
O blessed bond of board and bed!
’Tis Hymen peoples every town,
High wedlock then be honored.
Honor, high honor, and renown
To Hymen, god of every town!

speech.speaker: DUKE S.
speech.line: O my dear niece, welcome thou art to me,
Even daughter, welcome, in no less degree.

speech.speaker: PHE.
speech.line: I will not eat my word, now thou art mine,
Thy faith my fancy to thee doth combine.

speech.speaker: JAQ. DE B.
speech.line: Let me have audience for a word or two.
I am the second son of old Sir Rowland,
That bring these tidings to this fair assembly.
Duke Frederick, hearing how that every day
Men of great worth resorted to this forest,
Address’d a mighty power, which were on foot
In his own conduct, purposely to take
His brother here, and put him to the sword;
And to the skirts of this wild wood he came;
Where, meeting with an old religious man,
After some question with him, was converted
Both from his enterprise and from the world,
His crown bequeathing to his banish’d brother,
And all their lands restor’d to them again
That were with him exil’d. This to be true,
I do engage my life.

speech.speaker: DUKE S.
speech.line: Welcome, young man;
Thou offer’st fairly to thy brothers’ wedding:
To one his lands withheld, and to the other
A land itself at large, a potent dukedom.
First, in this forest let us do those ends
That here were well begun and well begot;
And after, every of this happy number,
That have endur’d shrewd days and nights with us,
Shall share the good of our returned fortune,
According to the measure of their states.
Mean time, forget this new-fall’n dignity,
And fall into our rustic revelry.
Play, music, and you brides and bridegrooms all,
With measure heap’d in joy, to th’ measures fall.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: Sir, by your patience.—If I heard you rightly,
The Duke hath put on a religious life,
And thrown into neglect the pompous court?

speech.speaker: JAQ. DE B.
speech.line: He hath.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: To him will I. Out of these convertites
There is much matter to be heard and learn’d.
You to your former honor I bequeath,
Your patience and your virtue well deserves it;
You to a love, that your true faith doth merit;
You to your land, and love, and great allies;
You to a long and well-deserved bed;
And you to wrangling, for thy loving voyage
Is but for two months victuall’d.—So to your pleasures,
I am for other than for dancing measures.

speech.speaker: DUKE S.
speech.line: Stay, Jaques, stay.

speech.speaker: JAQ.
speech.line: To see no pastime I. What you would have
I’ll stay to know at your abandon’d cave.

speech.speaker: DUKE S.
speech.line: Proceed, proceed. We’ll begin these rites,
As we do trust they’ll end, in true delights.

speech.speaker: ROS.
speech.line: It is not the fashion to see the lady the epilogue; but it is no more unhandsome than to see the lord the prologue. If it be true that good wine needs no bush, ’tis true that a good play needs no epilogue. Yet to good wine they do use good bushes; and good plays prove the better by the help of good epilogues. What a case am I in then, that am neither a good epilogue, nor cannot insinuate with you in the behalf of a good play! I am not furnish’d like a beggar, therefore to beg will not become me. My way is to conjure you, and I’ll begin with the women. I charge you, O women, for the love you bear to men, to like as much of this play as please you; and I charge you, O men, for the love you bear to women (as I perceive by your simp’ring, none of you hates them), that between you and the women the play may please. If I were a woman I would kiss as many of you as had beards that pleas’d me, complexions that lik’d me, and breaths that I defied not; and I am sure, as many as have good beards, or good faces, or sweet breaths, will for my kind offer, when I make curtsy, bid me farewell.
